dict.string:
Active Voice
Subject PERFORMS the action of the verb
Passive Voice
Focuses on action rather than the subject
Example
Active
He writes a letter
Passive
A letter is written by him

How to change active to passive
Move the subject to the beginning of the sentence

Example:
Passive Voice:
The tree was hit by the car
Active Voice:
The car hit the tree

How to change passive to active
Change the SUBJECT to be the OBJECT of the VERB.

Example:
Passive Voice:
The car hit the tree
Active Voice:
The tree was hit by the car

When to use active and passive

Passive voice is used to avoid taking responsibility for an action

Active voice is direct,clear, and concise. 

Passive voice is awkward when an author uses "it" as the receiver rather than using "I" or "we"

Example
It is concluded that the treatment is effective.

If passive voice is not constructed properly,it may have grammatical errors such as Dangling modifiers

Example:
Incorrect passive voice
To investigate the source of nutrients, eggshell membranes were compared.

The phrase modifies the only subject "eggshell". The sentence is not clear.

Corrected sentence
To investigate the source of nutrients, we compared eggshell membranes

Don't Underestimate These Three Little Words

In English, there are only three articles: the, a, and an

These three are not interchangeable; rather, they are used
in specific instances.

There are two types of articles:
  • Indefinite articles (an,a)
  • Definite articles ( the )

How do I know which one to use?
The answer is quite simple.
For indefinite article:
Use 'a ' before nouns (or adjectives) that start with a consonant sound.
Use 'an' before singular nouns (or adjectives) that start with a vowel sound.

Example:
  • Please give the dog a cookie. 
  • That's an old car.
Remember:
  • an hour
In the above sentence, You might think that 'a'
must come before a constant. But hour pronounced
like our which gives a vowel sound.

  •  A union
The word may start with a u, but 'union' is pronounced
as you-union. Therefore we have to use 'a'.

The definite article (the)
'The' is used before singular and plural nouns
when the noun is specific or particular.
'The' signals that the noun is definite.
Example:

"The dog that bit me ran away"
Here, we're talking about a specific dog, the dog that bit me.

Wrong sentence:
Aeroplane is the fastest means of travel that is in common use.
Correct sentence:
The Aeroplane is the fastest means of travel that is in common use

Wrong sentence:
He gave me an advice.
Correct sentence:
He gave me some advice.
Note:
'a' and 'an' are used before countable nouns.
When uncountable noun (advice) is used, 'some' is used.

Dangling participles

Dangling participles are tricky words or phrases that change the meaning of a sentence so that we don't say exactly what we intend.

What is a participle?
A participle usually acts a adjective.
 These are usually noun forms of the verbs.
Example:
Hiking shoes.

Participle phrases
These are just phrases that contain a participle and modify the sentence.
Example
Floating in the pool, I marveled at the clouds
"Floating" is the participle in the phrase "floating in the pool
It modifies the subject "I"

Example:
Biting his victim, the vampire felt a momentary thrill.

Dangling Participles:

When you dangle a participle, it means your participial phrase is hanging
 there in your sentence with no proper subject in sight.
Example
Hiking the trail, the birds chirped loudly.

In the above sentence, it seems that it is the birds hiking the trail

Correct sentence:
Hiking the trail, Squiggly and Aardvark heard birds chirping loudly.

More Examples
Rushing to the catch the bus, Bob's wallet fell out of his pocket.
Flying south for the winter, I saw a huge flock of swallows.
Walking along the beach, the sun rose majestically over the ocean

How to fix it
Add the subject to which the phrase is referring to and rephrase he sentence.

Positive Degree
This form can be used to compare items when combined with 'as'.
Example
Josh is as smart as kelsey
Note:
The adjective(smart) is placed between "as".
The adjective is unaltered.
Example
His house is not as big as that one.
big-adjective.

Comparative degree
It is used when you compare two objects
"-er" is added to the adjective
    smart-er
    fast-er
    smooth-er
But sometimes you need to add more or less before the adjective.
    less attractive
    more attractive
Example
This house is bigger than that one
This flower is more beautiful than that.

Comparative degree
When to add "more" or "-er"
Most one syllable and two syllable adjectives that end in "y" end in "-er"

Eg:calmer.
Adjectives with more than two syllables use "more"
Eg: more beautiful.
However there are exceptions to this. Refer the dictionary.
Important Point
When you are using adjectives ending "-er" in the same list with adjectives that use "more",
the adjective with "more" should come last in the list.
Example:
She is smarter,smaller, and more beautiful than kylie is

Superlative Degree
Compares three or more items and is considered the greatest degree.
Many superlatives end with -est
Eg: smartest,fastest and smoothest
Example
He has the highest grade in the group.
Irregular adjectives
These words are irregular because you have to change the entire word instead of just adding -er or -est.
For example
little--less-least.
good-better-best.

Faulty comparisons
There are some absolute words like perfect and unique. There is no degree of comparison
Example:
Wrong:
He wrote the most perfect correspondence today.
 Correct:
He wrote a perfect correspondence.

Ambigious comparisons
The comparison needs to be perfect.
Incomplete
He is not as mean.
Complete
He is not as mean as she is.
Incomplete
He scored more points in this basketball game.
Complete
He scored more points than she did in the last game

Illogical comparisons
Illogical comparisons occur when two or more items are compared, but the items are not in the same category

Example:
The flowers in quiton's yard are prettier than jacob.
This example includes a comparison between two items that are not in the same category- flowers and person.

Logical sentence
The flowers in quiton's yard are prettier than the ones in jacob's yard
This example compares flowers against flowers

Parts of Speech
Each part of speech explains how the word is used.
 
There are seven parts of speech in English
  • Nouns
  • Verbs
  • Pronouns
  • Adjective
  • Adverbs
  • Preposition
  • Conjunction

Important classes:
  1. Nouns-  These are names of people things or ideas.Eg: man,car,India
  2. Verbs-   Action words Eg:go, eat, sit,stand.
  3. Adjectives- These describe nouns. Eg: old man, Dangerous man.
  4. Adverbs- These describe verbs.(Ends in -ly).  Eg: beautifully.
  5. Perpostions: Short words used before a noun to show time or place.

Common Mistakes:
  • Many people prefer to buy Malaysia products.
  • That man is a Dangerously driver.

Correct sentence:
  • Many people prefer to buy Malaysian Product.
  • That man is a dangerous driver.
Explanation:
1) 'Malaysia' and 'product' are nouns.  A noun cannot describe a noun.
     Thefore adjective Malaysian must be used.
2)  Dangerously is an adverb; To describe the noun ‘driver’,
      the adjective dangerous must be used.

Noun or Adjectives

Typical mistakes:
  • My sister is an intelligence person
  • All races must live in peaceful and harmony
Correct sentence:
  •  My sister is an intelligent person.
  •  All races must live in peace and harmony.
Explanation:
1) Adjective is needed to describe a noun (person)
2) a preposition (in) always follows by a noun.

Pronouns
Pronouns are small words that the place of a noun.
If we didn't have pronouns, we would have to repeat a lot of nouns.

Example
Sentence without pronoun
Do you like the president? I don't like the president. The president is too pompous.
Sentence with pronoun
Do you like the president? I don't like him. He is too pompous.

Types of pronouns

Personal Pronouns
I, me, you, he, him, she...

Demonstrative Pronouns
this, that, these, those

Possessive Pronouns
mine, yours, his...

Reflexive Pronouns
myself, yourself, himself...

Relative Pronouns
who, whom, which...

Your and You're

The word your is  a possessive pronoun. The word shows ownership.

The word you're means "you are"

Is that your glass?
Is it your car,isn't it?

You're my friend.

Their vs They're
Their is a possessive pronoun.  
They're means "they are".
Example
Their book is on the table.
They're my best friends.

Its and it's
The word "its" is the possessive pronoun.
It's means "it is".
The book is missing all of its pages.
it’s around the corner.

Whom vs who
"Whom" is used to refer to the object of the sentence.
"Who" is used to refer to the subject of the sentence.
Whom do I love ?
You are asking about the object.
Who stepped on him?
Here you are asking about the subject:the performer of the action

Whose
"Whose" is a possessive pronoun like "his," "her" and "our."

We use "whose" to find out which person something belongs to.
Whose camera is this ?
Key Point
Ask yourself if the sentence requires a subject, object, or possessive form

Pronoun-Antecedent Agreement:
The antecedent is the noun that the pronoun replaces.
The pronoun must agree with the antecedent in number
Wrong: Each person must take their coat to the dry cleaner.
Right:  Everyone must take his or her coat to the dry cleaner.
Right: All the players must take their coats to the dry cleaner.

Question tags
Question tag is a mini-question at the end of a statement.
We use tag question at the end of a statement to ask for confirmation
Example
Snow is white,isn't it?
You don't like me, do you?

How to form the question tags?
General rule
Rule #1
For positive question, add negative question
It isn't raining, is it?

Rule #2
For negative question, add positive question
He should try hard, shouldn't he?

Same way question tags
We use same-way question tags to express interest, surprise, anger etc, and not to make real questions.
Example
So you think that's amusing, do you? Think again.

Exceptions
The expression aren’t I is often used in place of am I not, particularly in conversational speech.
Incorrect usage
I’m going with you on vacation, aren’t I?
Correct usage
I’m going with you on vacation, am I not?

Reflexive pronouns
Reflexive pronouns and intensive pronouns are those forms of pronouns that end in self or selves

myself
yourself
himself,herself,itself
ourselves
yourselves.
themselves
Reflexive pronouns are used when the object and the subject of the sentence are same.

Examples
Reflexive pronoun as direct object of verb
He asked himself if he could pass the exam

Reflexive pronouns as object of the preposition
He made a fool of himself.
She did all the research by herself.

Inappropriate use of reflexive pronouns

Incorrect:
He invited my wife and myself for the dinner.
Correct:
He invited my wife and me for the dinner.
Since the subject is "He" and not "I",the object of the verb is not the same as the subject, therefore the reflexive pronoun is not required 

Incorrect:
I'm fine--and yourself?
Correct:
I'm fine and you?

Incorrect:
This is a matter that concerns only you and himself.
Correct:
This is a matter that concerns only you and him.

Subject Verb Agreement
If you want to write proper English, you have to follow a rule called "subject-verb agreement."

Two basic rules
If the subject is singular, the verb needs to be singular.
If the subject is plural, the verb needs to be plural.

Examples
The duck quacks. (singular subject with singular verb)
Ducks quack.    (plural subject with plural verb)

The problem

The problem arises when there are two subjects.
In such cases you may have problems in deciding to which subject the verb should agree.

There are six rules which will make things clear.

Rule 1
Two singular subjects connected with "and" are plural, and need a plural verb.

Example
My mother and my father are visiting me.


Wrong usuage:
My mother and my father is visiting me.

Rule 2
Two singular subjects connected with the conjunctions or or nor need a singular verb.

Example
My mother or my father is going to call me today.

Note
If one of the subjects is plural, use the plural verb
We put the plural subject closest to the verb.
In other words,the verb agrees with the closest subject.
Example
The general or his advisers are responsible for the decision
advisors-plural. and closest to the verb.

Rule 3
Don’t get distracted if there’s another phrase between the subject and the verb.

Example
My sister, along with her children, is visiting me next month.

The verb needs to agree with the subject, not with other nouns that happen to precede the verb.

Rule 4
Words such as
  • either
  • neither
  • everyone 
  • everybody
  • anyone 
  • anybody 
  • someone
  • one
  • none 
  • each
are singular and need a singular verb.
Example:
One of my friends is playing football.

Rule 5
fractions or portions of a plural noun are still plural
often these are expressed with prepositions.
Points to remember
Use a singular verb if the object of the preposition is singular, but a plural verb if it’s plural.
Example:
  • Some of the students are wealthy
  • Half of the campus is covered with trees.

Rule 6
Time and money are singular
Example:
Five rupees is very little money

A preposition links nouns,pronouns and phrases to other words in a sentence.
A preposition indicates temporal,spatial or logical relationships of its objects to the rest of the sentence.


Eg:
The book is on the table
The book is beneath the table.
The book is leaning against the table.

Preposition introduces the noun in the sentence.
Eg:
The children climbed the mountain without fear
"without" introduces the noun "fear"

The spider crawled slowly along the banister.
"along" introduces the noun "the banister".

Beside and besides
Beside means "by the side of"
Besides means "in addition to"

Example:
The house was beside the river
He stood beside me

Since and For
Since refers to the starting point in the of an action in the past.

Wrong sentence:
He is absent since last monday
Correct sentence:
He has been absent since last monday
"Since" is always used with present perfect.

For
For is used to talk about duration. It refers to a period of time.
I have been waiting here for two hours.

Common Error
He has been absent since two days’

Between and among
We use between to say that somebody or something is between two or more clearly separate objects.

Example:
You have to choose between these two options.
I stood between John and Peter.

Among is used with more than two people or things.
Example:
The United Nations tries to maintain peace among the nations of the world.

In and At
In is generally used to refer to large places – countries, districts, large cities etc.
At is generally used to refer to small and unimportant places like villages, small towns etc.

Example
We shall meet them at the club this evening.
My brother lives at Mumbai.

This rule is not very rigidly followed.

On, in, at and by
at indicates an exact point of time
on: a more general point of time
in: a period of time

Example
I shall be there at 4 pm
I was born on May 26.
I shall visit them in summer

By
By is used to show the latest time at which an action will be finished.
So it is usually used with the future tenses.
I shall be leaving by 6 o’ clock.
I hope to finish the work by the end of this year.

On and upon
On is generally used to talk about things at rest and upon to talk about things in motion.
He sat on a chair.
He jumped upon his horse.

In and within (time)
"In" means at the end of a certain period; "within" means before the end of a certain period.
The spacecraft will reach the moon in three days. (= at the end of three days)
The loan should be repaid in a year.

Conjunctions
A conjunction is merely a connecting word. It has no other function in the sentence.

One conjunction for two clauses:
One conjunction is enough to join two clauses.
  • Although he is poor, he is honest.
  • He is poor but he is honest.

Correct use of some conjunctions

Unless
Unless means if not. It is uncommon to start sentences with if not.

Correct Sentence:
Unless you give the keys of the safe, you will be shot.

Wrong Sentence:
Unless you do not give the keys of the safe, you will be shot.
Because Unless means if not. Adding another not makes the sentence go wrong.

Lest
Lest means "that... not"
It is wrong to add another "not".
Examples
Correct sentence
Take care lest you fall
Wrong sentence
Take care lest you do not fall.

Than, as and that
Than is used after comparative adjectives and adverbs. As and that are not used after comparatives

Correct Sentence:
She is taller than me.
Wrong Sentence:
She is taller as me.

As…as…
As is used in comparisons of equality’.
Than and that are not used in this way.
Examples:
My hands were as cold as ice.
Your eyes are the same colour as mine.

Common errors
Incorrect
Because he was not ready therefore we left without him
Correct
Because he was not ready we left without him
"Because" is enough to join two clauses. There is no need to use "therefore"

Incorrect
She did not come to school. Because she was ill.
Correct:
She did not come to school because she was ill.
Common punctuation mistake. Because cannot be used to start a sentence.

Incorrect sentence:
No sooner I had reached the station than the train left.
Correct sentence:
No sooner had I reached the station than the train left.

When no sooner comes at the beginning of a sentence, we use an inverted word order

Incorrect Sentence:
Neither he comes nor he writes.
Correct Sentence:
Neither does he come nor does he write
When the first word is negative, the auxillary verb comes before the subject.

Incorrect sentence:
Their front door was open and there was nobody at home
Correct Sentence:
Their front door was open but there was nobody at home.
But is used when the second clause introduces unexpected results.
